title.narrative: Securing a sustainable coffee supply chain

description.narrative: In Colombia, due to the lack of a quality-based value chain, challenging infrastructure, and existing culture and traditions dominating the coffee sector, many smallholder specialty coffee farmers are forced to sell their coffee as normal coffee at lower prices and do not have access to international markets. Furthermore, coffee is traditionally treated as a commodity where profits often end up with the importers and traders rather than the smallholder farmers who produce the coffee. This leads to loss of income, quality decrease and unreached potential of specialty coffee and causes many farmers to live in poverty. A paradoxical situation, as the demand for specialty coffee in Europe continues to rise and international specialty coffee traders have difficulties meeting market demands.The Coffee Quest is a Dutch green coffee importer whose vision it is to create a balanced value chain for producers, traders, roasters and others to improve coffee quality and production capacity and with this, providing market access and premium prices to smallholder farmers in hopes to improve their livelihoods and incomes. In order to meet market demands and increase capacity, Technical Assistance (DGGF-TA) provided support to The Coffee Quest and its partners Medellin Mill SAS and TMO Import Export SAS. The project included the development of a value chain, the set-up of a specialty coffee mill and 3 coffee buying stations in different regions, the set-up of an automated quality control system and transparent and digital payment system based on quality rather than quantity, as well as training of local farmers regarding quality improvement, sustainable and organic farming. The project supported 17 FTE direct jobs, of which 15 fulltime employees and an additional 2 to 6 seasonal workers per day during harvest season, and 662 indirect jobs, including 650 coffee farming families who were able to sell their specialty coffee at higher than markets prices. The project also provided training to 225 people, of which 200 smallholder farmers who have increased their incomes with 10% to 30% already. The project was successful and the first 160 tons of Colombian specialty coffee milled by the Coffee Quest has been sold in Europe. Further investments in training and certifying local farmers for organic specialty coffee, as well as opening more buying stations in order to source more specialty coffee in Colombia are being prepared and may result in 30 direct jobs and higher incomes and new income streams for 2,000 to 3,000 smallholder farmers within the next 3 years.
